title: Episode 111 – Gero Leson, “Honor Thy Label” on Dr. Bronner’s Global Regenerative Relationships
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[10.7s - 17.4s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[17.7s - 23.5s]: we're visiting with the author of Honor Thy Label, Garo Lazon, Hi Garo.

[24.6s - 25.9s]: Hey Aaron, thanks for having me.

[25.9s - 27.9s]: Yeah, it's great to have you on. How are you today?

[29.1s - 30.8s]: Little sick, but it's not COVID.

[31.2s - 33.1s]: Okay, that's good. I'm nice to see that.

[34.4s - 40.5s]: Garo Lazon, in addition to being the author of Honor Thy Label, is vice president of special

[40.5s - 47.5s]: operations at Dr. Bronners. Since 2005, he has managed Dr. Bronner's shift to sourcing its

[47.5s - 53.3s]: main ingredients from organic and fair-to-trade projects. These ingredients are coconut,

[53.3s - 59.1s]: palm, olive, several essential oils, sugar, alcohol, and now, coca beans.

[60.3s - 66.8s]: Garo's special operations team of AIT has built and operates several integrated farming and

[66.8s - 73.5s]: processing projects with local partner teams. These involve hundreds to thousands of small

[73.5s - 79.9s]: holder farmers processing operations with two to three hundred people in staff and significant

[79.9s - 85.5s]: social impact through hands-on engagement in education, healthcare, and infrastructure development.

[86.1s - 91.8s]: The special ops team also works closely with and purchases from other projects not owned by Dr.

[92.0s - 98.2s]: Bronners, such as Canaan Palestine and the West Bank. In recent years, all projects are emphasizing

[98.2s - 104.7s]: the shift to regenerative agriculture to improve soil productivity, resilience, and carving sequestration.

[105.7s - 111.2s]: Born in Cologne, Germany, Garo has a master's degree in physics from the University of Cologne,

[111.5s - 118.2s]: and a doctorate in environmental science and engineering from UCLA. Before working for Dr.

[118.4s - 123.6s]: Bronners, he worked as an environmental consultant to US industry in the development and industrial

[123.6s - 130.8s]: hemp and in international development. When not traveling, he lives in Berkeley, California. Now,

[130.8s - 136.2s]: Garo, I know this last little bit about you not traveling. You do a heck of a lot of traveling,

[136.2s - 140.8s]: it seems. Just the process of coordinating our interview together,

[141.4s - 146.4s]: required several weeks as you were, I think, a broad visiting some of your projects. And I thought

[146.4s - 153.1s]: I would just dive right in by asking you, what is it that has you traveling so much and connecting

[153.1s - 159.5s]: with communities all around the world? And how is that approach, which you're spearheading for Dr.

[159.5s - 168.2s]: Bronners, different from how many of the other more mainstream industrial companies are doing

[168.2s - 176.0s]: things with regard to their supply chains? You hit it right on the head, Aaron. How do we differentiate

[176.0s - 183.4s]: ourselves from companies that simply and not that simple, simply by organic and fad trade ingredients

[183.4s - 192.1s]: were available? And that takes us back a little bit to the story really of our work on our supply

[192.1s - 201.9s]: chain. So my bosses, the grandsons of the company founder, Emmanuel Bronner, when they took over

[201.9s - 210.0s]: in around 2000, it was clear they wanted to continue his vision, his vision being cleaning up the

[210.0s - 216.7s]: world with soap. Honestly, he was Emmanuel was driven enough to think that that's his responsibility

[216.7s - 223.1s]: as an entrepreneur. Now his sons have more, have more improved technical means at their hands,

[223.1s - 229.4s]: like there's things such as the internet. And but then they also had a little more sales and they

[229.4s - 238.5s]: had their mom to help and run the company on the financial side. And the question then came up,

[238.5s - 246.1s]: where do our ingredients come from? In 2003, they said, oh, let's shift to organic. That seems to be

[246.1s - 253.7s]: something that shows responsibility and you avoid farm workers in the tropics from being sprayed

[253.7s - 259.3s]: with pesticides. And after a year buying organic coconut, all they realized, oh, we're just buying

[259.3s - 264.4s]: from a broker. And we still don't know where the oil is coming from. And then David whom I knew by

[264.4s - 271.4s]: then from our work in him, who he said, and I was working in Sri Lanka on a development project. And

[271.4s - 277.1s]: he said, can you look around for fair trade coconut oil? Because he thought we need something that's

[277.1s - 283.8s]: third party verified. You want some sort of a certification system because he's very well aware

[284.7s - 293.4s]: of this tendency to just do label fraud or to just lie and embellish whatever you do. So we

[293.4s - 298.6s]: start looking around and then we realized, well, there's no standards. There's no fair trade standards

[298.6s - 305.6s]: for any of our ingredients, right? There's fair trade standards for coffee, cocoa, sugar,

[306.0s - 311.9s]: and not for us. And it was because there was a monopoly by the fair trade international.

[313.0s - 319.5s]: Really on and they didn't have much of an incentive to move ahead and just expand their system.

[319.5s - 325.8s]: So we looked around, found comparable standards number one and then realized there's no supply

[325.8s - 331.6s]: still. So we have to do this ourselves. And then crazy enough, we started building our first

[331.6s - 338.5s]: coconut oil factory in Sri Lanka because that's where I had been doing consulting work in

[341.4s - 347.1s]: in Sri Lanka and had developed friendly relationships with business people there whom I trusted.

[392.2s - 397.6s]: maintain these are group certifications to maintain that system. You have to do the architecture

[413.2s - 419.9s]: done this in several other locations and that's really what's kept me traveling for the last 15

[537.2s - 543.2s]: the cover here, some folks who are looking at the video version of our discussion. Really a beautiful

[543.2s - 550.4s]: cover and wonderful way of storytelling, describing many of your experiences that you're also

[550.4s - 558.4s]: conveying, many of the principles and practices that you and your team use. But one of the things

[558.4s - 565.8s]: that really jumped out at me is how important it is to have those relationships with those community

[565.8s - 571.5s]: leaders on the ground and business leaders on the ground. It seems that that's really the

[571.5s - 578.8s]: link in the global shame that when it's strong, probably means a lot of good things are happening

[578.8s - 584.6s]: and perhaps when it's not going so well, it can really cause trouble throughout the entire

[585.4s - 592.2s]: organization. This is one of the key challenges. Aaron is really to find the right people.

[592.8s - 599.4s]: Everybody will tell you this, right? That's just well known. And we've made our mistakes.

[599.8s - 605.1s]: There were two cases of fraud on two projects and we ultimately had to let the managers go.

[605.8s - 612.6s]: And I hadn't done this before. So I had to learn. But in that process, you develop a better nose

[613.3s - 620.1s]: for who's driven by what motivations. And you want to pick people that do have a motivation that

[620.1s - 624.8s]: goes beyond just making money. There's nothing wrong with people wanting to make a living. But if you

[624.8s - 631.9s]: provide some meaning and purpose, you will have not a guarantee, but your likelihood of more

[631.9s - 640.8s]: loyalty is important. So unlike bigger companies who may have local subsidiaries and then

[640.8s - 649.4s]: hire the CEO and let them do things, we get very closely involved in the development of staff.

[650.6s - 657.8s]: And to a point that's pretty common here now is you do leadership training and team building.

[657.8s - 664.2s]: All these nice terms, you have to do that on the ground. Because number one, there's

[664.2s - 670.1s]: succession issues. And number two, it helps on motivation that you build teams. So we've just

[679.4s - 687.5s]: Yet, and that, I'd say overall, has had a very beneficial impact. So we just take the time to

[687.5s - 694.7s]: speak to encourage our people on the ground. They're also remote. So you want to integrate them

[694.7s - 700.6s]: into what you do, give them speaking opportunities at webinars or live, for instance. It's the

[715.1s - 720.3s]: an opportunity to speak, to like-minded about their experience, just gives exposure.

[766.7s - 767.9s]: We like to enact.

[769.6s - 777.7s]: Yeah, I love hearing about this psychological and human relationships side of the work you're doing.

[854.0s - 858.4s]: this up because we hadn't done this before and I was really concerned about getting things wrong,
